<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 119, 92, 137]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 875, 153]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate how the motion of a pendulum whose swing is interrupted depends on its length.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 165, 144, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 180, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 163, 875, 199]]<|/det|>
Lay the pendulum next to the rule and use the pen to make a mark on the string so that the distance \(L\) is \(0.180 \text{m}\), as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 208, 803, 351]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 355, 529, 373]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 73, 181, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 875, 107]]<|/det|>
Set up the apparatus, fixing the string in the split bung so that the string is just touching the wooden rod at the mark you have made.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 78, 945, 120]]<|/det|>
<form>For Examiner's Use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 117, 693, 138]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.2 shows a side view and a front view of the apparatus.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 146, 816, 603]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 604, 530, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 636, 769, 655]]<|/det|>
The centre of the bob should be approximately \(5\mathrm{cm}\) above the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 667, 875, 701]]<|/det|>
The distance \(x\) between the bottom of the bung and the centre of the bob should be approximately \(55\mathrm{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 713, 725, 732]]<|/det|>
The mark on the string should be level with the centre of the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 745, 180, 763]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 745, 487, 763]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the distance \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 791, 876, 809]]<|/det|>
<form>x = .................................................... m [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 180, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 875, 106]]<|/det|>
Move the bob sideways through a distance of approximately \(5\mathrm{cm}\), as shown in Fig. 1.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 119, 626, 368]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 387, 531, 406]]<|/det|>
<mark>[i]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 419, 181, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 418, 875, 469]]<|/det|>
Release the bob and watch its movement. The bob will move to the right and then to the left again completing a swing, as shown in Fig. 1.4. Let the pendulum swing to and fro, counting the number of swings.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 477, 606, 700]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[403, 691, 574, 708]]<|/det|>
one complete swing

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 728, 531, 747]]<|/det|>
<mark>[i]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 758, 720, 777]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the time for at least 10 consecutive swings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 789, 875, 824]]<|/det|>
Record enough readings to determine an accurate value for the time \(T\) taken for one complete swing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 912, 875, 931]]<|/det|>
<form>T = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 875, 107]]<|/det|>
Reduce the distance \(x\). Keep \(L\) constant, by adjusting the height of the wooden rod if necessary. Repeat **(a)**(iii) and **(b)** until you have six sets of values of \(x\) and \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[898, 78, 945, 92]]<|/det|>
<form>For

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 89, 945, 104]]<|/det|>
Examiner's

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[900, 101, 928, 116]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 437, 136]]<|/det|>
Include values of \(\sqrt{x}\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 429, 875, 448]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 459, 146, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 459, 178, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 458, 653, 477]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\mathcal{T}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\sqrt{x}\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 459, 875, 477]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 489, 180, 508]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 489, 457, 508]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 489, 875, 508]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 520, 183, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 520, 608, 539]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 725, 873, 744]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ......................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 771, 875, 789]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 72, 714, 92]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 78, 945, 120]]<|/det|>
<form>Examiner's Use</FORM>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 118, 94, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 116, 875, 153]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate how the force required to pull a block up an inclined plane depends on the angle between the inclined plane and the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 165, 144, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 165, 180, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 164, 445, 183]]<|/det|>
Place the board on the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 196, 180, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 196, 875, 231]]<|/det|>
Place the block with attached masses on the board, and attach the newton-meter as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 241, 833, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 390, 529, 409]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 422, 180, 441]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 422, 712, 441]]<|/det|>
Gently pull the newton-meter until the block just starts to move.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 453, 875, 488]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the reading \(F_0\) on the newton-meter, at the instant the block just starts to move.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[539, 606, 875, 626]]<|/det|>
<form>F_0 = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 640, 180, 658]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 640, 655, 658]]<|/det|>
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(F_0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[373, 763, 875, 782]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = ................................................. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 810, 181, 828]]<|/det|>
<label>(v)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 803, 411, 833]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(\mu\) where \(\mu = \frac{F_0}{W}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 855, 791, 874]]<|/det|>
W is the value of the weight of the block and masses written on the card.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 919, 875, 937]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\mu =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 73, 180, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 875, 107]]<|/det|>
Place the board and supporting block as shown in Fig. 2.2. The longer edge of the supporting block should be vertical.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 114, 811, 250]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 265, 531, 284]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 295, 181, 314]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 295, 875, 330]]<|/det|>
Using the protractor, measure and record the angle \(\theta\) between the board and the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 388, 875, 406]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta =\)  ....................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 419, 180, 438]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 419, 749, 439]]<|/det|>
Using your values from (a)(v) and (b)(ii), calculate \((\sin \theta + \mu \cos \theta)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 527, 876, 546]]<|/det|>
<form>(sin \(\theta\) + \(\mu \cos \theta\)) = .................................................. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 559, 144, 578]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 559, 180, 578]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 559, 875, 593]]<|/det|>
Place the block with masses on the board and attach it to the newton-meter, as shown in Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 603, 744, 740]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 752, 531, 771]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 782, 181, 801]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 782, 655, 801]]<|/det|>
Pull the newton-meter until the block just starts to move.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 814, 655, 832]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the reading \(F\) on the newton-meter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 907, 876, 925]]<|/det|>
<form>F = .................................................... [1]
